conclusion: Understand the relationship between the position of the small ball and its shadow on the wall.
The point light source is located at a distance d away from the vertical wall.
The small ball is thrown vertically upwards from the midpoint, which is also at a distance d from the wall.
The shadow of the small ball will be projected onto the wall such that the angle of incidence equals the angle of refraction.
Denote h(t) as the height of the ball at time t and s(t) as the horizontal distance of the shadow from the wall at time t.
The initial height when the ball is thrown is y_0 = d/2.
Use the property of similar triangles: s/d = (d - h)/y_0.
Substitute y_0 = d/2 into the equation: s/d = 2(d - h)/d.
Simplify the equation to s = 2(d - h).
The ball's vertical motion is described by the kinematic equation for free fall under gravity: h(t) = v_0 t - (1/2) g t^2.
Relate the motion of the ball and shadow: s(t) = 2(d - v_0 t + (1/2) g t^2).
At t = 0, the ball is at its initial height y_0 = d/2, and the shadow is at s(0).
Using the formula for s(t) at t = 0: s(0) = 2(d - d/2) = d.
The shadow starts at a distance equal to the distance from the light source to the wall initially.
Determine initial velocity v_0 using kinematic equations and geometric similarity.
At t = 0, height h(0) = y_0 = d/2, so s(0) = 2(d - d/2) = d.
v_0 = sqrt(g d/2) using the equation derived from Kinematics.
The initial velocity of the shadow is sqrt(g d/2).
